title: There should be rules against holding people hostage in a game
body:
I got stuck with 2 COMPLETE fuckboy players who fed the HELL outta their lanes then refused to surrender when they went and fed the other lanes and proceeded to blame me for no back up (I was jungle) and when my team tried to surrender they said "just have fun, never surrender" and SPAMMED THE LIVING FUCK OUTTA THAT MESSAGE.

honestly this is why I hate parties in general, they ruin things because they wanna be dickheads and troll.

However, if games are +120min, IE **Two goddamn hours**, then it should prioritize those games over hour and a half matches (which I've been in a few before - very tense, very hard, and very tireing. Of the five times that has happened, I did not once not honor opponents, so long as they stuck with it. Same for teammates) for human review - THAT is a fairly simple setup.

However, acting that these matches aren't 'taken hostage' is bullshit. You don't believe me? Longest game on record for League of Legends is upwards six hours, excluding custom game where a bunch of people fucked around for like 7 1/2 hours until the game crashed itself automatically *which I assume is because the game has automated safeguards, but more likely than not something's scaling went to scientific and broke everything so hard it just died.*
There was also a game where a Kindred had +120 kills to 12 deaths.

Yeah, hostage games don't exist **MY ASS.**
In fact, low ELO in South America and Oceania servers have had cases of two groups of two that play infinitely stacking champions que up at the same time to take advantage of the low as hell playerbase on those servers, end up fighting eachother, get so fed they don't allow the enemy to win - FROM BOTH SIDES.

Uh running under enemy tower and using summs and giving first blood, then proceeding to just feed, feed, and feed

You're actually obligated by TOS to try your best to win every game and stay till the bitter end, regardless of what your teammates are doing. The report button at the end of the game exists -- report teammates who intentionally feed.

Learn the difference between "intentionally feeding", "being mechanically bad at the game", "playing a champion you aren't familiar with", "playing an off meta pick", "being in a bad matchup", "being camped", "making bad strategic decisions" and "i'm already 0/10 so this wave i'm overextending for is worth more gold than me". In most cases, unless they're actually running it down, building AP Garen, or following the jungler around the jungle stealing their camps when they're standing there fighting them, they aren't inting.

A 17/1/10 Akali who rages at you for taking her red buff and runs it down mid once before going back to killing everyone to pay you back for taking the red buff is intentionally feeding.
A 0/10/0 Caitlyn who has been overextending for farm since 0/5 is not intentionally feeding.

Overextending for farm isn't intentional feeding.
Taking a 1% play isn't intentional feeding.
Missing a flash over a wall isn't intentional feeding.
Missing skillshots isn't intentional feeding.
Using abilities in the wrong order isn't intentional feeding.
Making a bad strategic decision isn't intentional feeding.
Building suboptimally isn't intentional feeding.

In fact, attempting to surrender a game is by definition intentionally trying to lose and has a higher chance of losing your team the game than any action you can take on Summoner's Rift. 100% of all surrendered games have ended in a loss for the surrendering team, without a single exception in the entire history of League of Legends. This includes all levels of play from the depths of level 1 games to the World Finals, in every single region, every single patch, regardless of what champions are on the map or who's playing them, what the score is, or any other factor. Even if you took the full roster of Invictus or Fnatic or Team Liquid and pitted them against brand new level 1 players who've never seen a MOBA before, if the pros do /surrender, they will lose 100% of the time. It doesn't matter that they're the best players in the world or that they're 30k gold up or that their opponents don't know what the controls do, if they type /surrender they will lose.

No. If you're "being held hostage", you play your best and report people who are actually inting in the postgame lobby.

It's this kind of piss poor logic that keeps people locked in unwinnable games for sometimes over a half an hour. If riot *actually* thought a surrender vote violated tos they would remove it from the game. LOLOLOL

I agree with everything you typed up until the first surrender vote sentence. Initiating a surrender vote can have the opposite effect, waking your team up to the dire situation before them and make them realize that if they don't stop messing around, they could lose this game. Agreeing to the surrender vote however would indeed increase your chance of losing, and rather immediately I might add, but there are definitely other actions you can take to make it easier to lose. You're oversimplifying the way the surrender vote works and I honestly think that's pretty silly and I don't know why you are but you should take a step back and look at a bigger picture here.

You might have a point in implying he might have not been playing at his best because if he muted spammers he might have been able to focus a bit more on what truly mattered, but that's a matter of debate so I won't call you right or wrong by implying that.

Bottom line; play the game with the intent to win/have fun then report as needed when the game is over. If it is an egregious behavior, then you can get in touch with riot support to give them a heads up in addition to reporting them.
Use surrender vote and respect other people vote.

And as a heads up for those that will downvote me and maybe reply, yes i am part of the problem. You know who else is part of the problem? Those with the never surrender mentality.   On average people hate games that are well, hopeless. And dont get me started on games that you have to play perfectly.

You're actually right, if you're playing with a group that has no intention of playing the game normally, you have 2 options. Try to win despite their insanity, which given enough time, sometimes snaps them out of their chaotic mindset or you just wasted time and effort with that attempt and the alternative would be to temporarily accept that you're not playing the same game you signed up for and just do whatever while still participating as a team member.

Unfortunately, because we can't see who is in which groups, some people might jump to the wrong conclusion and might not even try to draw out chat evidence of groups they are matched with or perhaps more accurately they might get upset at being matched AGAINST good teamwork or groups which betrays a lack of sportsmanship. Either way, although in my mind I can't disagree that we see too much 'do whatever' play styles...I have to wonder if this would happen less/more often if RIot showed us the groups so that we don't jump to conclusions and make decisions about how to play the game that we might regret later.

I feel like if for no other reason, Riot should let us know who is in which groups so that it would be easier to be diplomatic towards them and it would be easier to accept diplomatic responses from those groups. It takes a different kind of strategy to talk to a different number of players because many groups simply won't allow us to talk to individuals. If we tell one player something, and they have friends playing with them on the team too, that message affects them personally and they will respond, whether in chat or not,  positively or negatively. 

Sometimes this matters when it comes to timing. It can be difficult to cooperate with a lane partner for example who is in a group because they might start talking to their friend before typing anything to me and then their friend starts flaming me for something that's none of their business. Whether I'm to blame or my lane partner is or neither of us is to blame, if I'd known they were part of a group before the game started and during the game, I'd actually think that maybe I should more quickly make my own report(tell the team what went wrong in our lane) so that they don't just let their rage fester and burst out in such a way that I will have to mute them both.
